key paragraph or sentence which sets the NAEB apart from other organ¬
izations of its type. If so, I would appreciate your pointing out
this paragraph or sentence to me* But, what I failed to find was
some such statement as this "The NAEB is primarily comprised of repre¬
sentatives, usually directors or managers, of educational stations
licensed to educational institutions, public school systems, non-profit
foundations and the like* One of the purposes of the organization is
to encourage educational broadcasters to operate their own stations.
It is the belief of the NAEB that the best job of educational broad¬
casting requires that the educational broadcaster be the licensee in
order that he might more adequately control the nature and number of
programs which he broadcasts."
The statement quoted above may go too far. It is not a
carefully worked out proposal. It is merely the kind of a statement
which you would dictate to your secretary in lieu of something better.
But it does convey what I understood to be the feeling of
Harold McCarty and I think yourself as old-time operators when I talked
to both of you at the meeting. If something like the above statement
represents the position of people like Mac and yourself then I think
you owe it to the body to make such a proposal.
And I can tell you where I would stand on such a proposal.
Personally I like it. I will frankly confess this represents a reversal
of my opinion as the result of talking to Mac and to you. When I made
my infamous "haive" speech ( in my favor let it be remembered that this
was the only time I did speak at the convention save when I gave my
report) I frankly did not see what we had to fear by giving associate
members an equal vote. Now I understand that the NAEB traditionally
has been, and indeed ought to be, primarily an organization of indi¬
viduals or institutions which operate their own educational broadcasting
stations. Let the AERT or some other body function primarily in the
service of other persons who use the air for educational purposes.
I could be completely wrong (naturally, I don*t believe this)
but it seems to me one of the reasons we did not get very far in our
discussions at the convention was that we failed to air this above issue
which is more basic than the one which we discussed. It seems to me
that if we once smoke out this basic issue there will be no smoke screen
hiding the true nature of the less basic issues which really hinge on
this primary issue of the function of the NAEB. Once we have decided
that the NAEB is to be the kind of organization described by the para¬
graph I have put in quotes above, it automatically follows that:
(1) There should be a difference in memberships, and
(2) a difference in the power of vote.
